G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum jurisdictional threshold of this Court and is within the jurisdictional limits of the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3 because the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business, and the incident occurred, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223A, § 3 because the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business, and the incident occurred, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: As a business invitee, Plaintiff was owed a duty of reasonable care by Defendant to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition, to inspect for and remedy dangerous conditions, and to warn of hazards that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focused on criticizing the continued reliance on entrant classifications (trespasser/licensee/invitee) after Mounsey; it does not state or affirm the specific duty owed to a business invitee to maintain premises, inspect, remedy dangers, and warn. In fact, Mounsey broadly rejects the invitee/licensee distinction in favor of a general reasonable care standard, so using this case for a proposition framed specifically in terms of a “business invitee” duty is inaccurate. The provided excerpt does not address or describe the detailed invitee duty stated in the proposition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors... The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places."

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: As a business invitee, Plaintiff was owed a duty of reasonable care by Defendant to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition, to inspect for and remedy dangerous conditions, and to warn of hazards that Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional duty owed to an invitee: to use reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe, including repairing or removing dangerous conditions or at least warning of non-obvious dangers the owner knew or should have known about. The court then generalizes this invitee standard to all lawful visitors. This directly matches the proposition that a business invitor owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain, inspect, remedy, and warn about hazards it knows or should know of.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” *Papadopoulos*, 457 Mass. at 371–72.

*Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, In.raw_text: *Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, Inc.*, 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986) (vicarious liability for employees acting within scope of employment).
*Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, In.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant’s employees were acting within the course and scope of their employment, and Defendant is responsible for their acts and omissions under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
*Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, In.case_name: Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc.
*Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, In.support_reasoning: The opinion directly analyzes whether an employer is liable, under respondeat superior principles, for an employee’s acts and discusses what it means for conduct to be within the scope of employment. The court holds that Joseph’s conduct in interfering with the contract was within the scope of his employment and that Wang is therefore legally responsible for his acts. This squarely supports the general proposition that when employees act within the course and scope of their employment, the employer is responsible for their acts and omissions under respondeat superior.
*Wang Labs., Inc. v. Bus. Incentives, In.relevant_excerpt: “We agree that Wang cannot be held liable under G. L. c. 93A for the conduct of an employee acting outside the scope of his employment. But, we are not persuaded that the judge found explicitly or implicitly that Joseph’s conduct was not within the scope of his employment. On the contrary, we are satisfied that the judge’s explicit findings…require the legal conclusion that Joseph’s conduct…was within the scope of his employment and was, therefore, Wang’s conduct.…[O]ur case law compels the conclusion that…Wang is legally responsible for the losses incurred by Post and BI….”

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to the condition of the property.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates the Massachusetts common-law rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises regarding the condition of the property. The court then elaborates that this duty includes maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers, thereby directly supporting the stated proposition about the scope of the landowner’s duty to lawful visitors.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “‘Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury.’ … An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. Id. at 743. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: This duty applies to business proprietors such as grocery stores, who must maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, remedy hazards within a reasonable time after they arise, and warn customers of dangers of which they know or reasonably should know.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the traditional Massachusetts rule that a store owner must maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition and has liability only after a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct hazards. While the case’s main contribution is adopting the mode-of-operation approach, it reaffirmes the underlying duty described in the proposition (safe premises, remedy hazards within a reasonable time, and the notice-based duty to warn). Thus it is good authority for that general duty of business proprietors such as grocery stores.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). However, the law has afforded store owners a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct any hazards before liability attaches.

*DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180.raw_text: *DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180 (1953) (storekeeper must use ordinary care to keep premises reasonably safe)
*DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care in the ownership, operation, management, inspection, and maintenance of the Premises, including the dairy aisle where the spill occurred.
*DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180.case_name: McCabe v. Liggett Drug Co. Inc.
*DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180.support_reasoning: The opinion is a products-liability / implied warranty case about an exploding coffee maker sold in a store; it does not concern premises liability, duties to business invitees, or the maintenance or inspection of store premises such as a dairy aisle. The court analyzes merchantability and notice under the sales statute, not the standard of care owed by a landowner or storekeeper to an invitee. Thus it does not support the asserted proposition about a duty of reasonable care in owning, operating, inspecting, or maintaining premises.
*DeCosta v. Cammack*, 330 Mass. 177, 180.relevant_excerpt: "The transaction appears to have been a sale by description... The sale carried an implied warranty by the seller that the appliance was a coffee maker of merchantable quality. G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 106, § 17 (2). Merchantable quality means that goods are reasonably suitable for the ordinary uses for which goods of that description are sold."

*Trimble v. Methodist Hosp.*, 436 Mass..raw_text: *Trimble v. Methodist Hosp.*, 436 Mass. 102, 106–07 (2002) (duty of care includes reasonable inspections).
*Trimble v. Methodist Hosp.*, 436 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care in the ownership, operation, management, inspection, and maintenance of the Premises, including the dairy aisle where the spill occurred.
*Trimble v. Methodist Hosp.*, 436 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a civil-rights/public-accommodations case about alleged sex discrimination at a religious men’s meeting and addresses whether the theater was a place of public accommodation and related First Amendment concerns. It does not concern premises liability, slip-and-fall, business invitees, or duties regarding inspection and maintenance of property. Consequently, it cannot be used as authority that a defendant owed a business invitee a duty of reasonable care in ownership, operation, management, inspection, and maintenance of premises such as a dairy aisle.
*Trimble v. Methodist Hosp.*, 436 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The public accommodation statutes, G. L. c. 272, §§ 92A and 98, prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, among other factors, in relation to the admission of or treatment of any person in a place of public accommodation. General Laws c. 272, § 92A, defines a place of public accommodation as “any place, whether licensed or unlicensed, which is open to and accepts or solicits the patronage of the general public,” and includes “an auditorium, theatre, music hall, meeting place or hall, including common halls of buildings.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: In Massachusetts, negligence is established where there exists (1) a duty of reasonable care, (2) a breach of that duty, (3) causation, and (4) damages.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements of negligence in Massachusetts, listing duty, breach, causation, and damages. Although it references a secondary source (Nolan & Sartorio) rather than another case for that specific sentence, the Supreme Judicial Court adopts and applies this four-part framework in its own statement of the law, so the case is proper authority for the proposition.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “3. Negligence claim. a. Duty of care, generally. To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005).”

*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.proposition: In Massachusetts, negligence is established where there exists (1) a duty of reasonable care, (2) a breach of that duty, (3) causation, and (4) damages.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements the plaintiffs must prove for negligence: breach of a duty of reasonable care, actual loss (damages), and causation. While it does not separately enumerate "duty" as the first element in a numbered list, it expressly references breach of the duty to use reasonable care and identifies causation and damages as essential elements, which matches the four-part formulation in the proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio, Inc.*, 430 Mass. 694.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 166–67 (1973) (premises liability where condition existed long enough that reasonable care would have discovered it).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Even if Defendant lacked actual knowledge at some earlier time, the size of the puddle and the presence of cart tracks through it demonstrate that the condition existed long enough that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it, thereby providing at least constructive notice.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The proposition relies on circumstantial features of a liquid (size, tracks) to argue the condition existed long enough to give constructive notice. Oliveri does recognize that a plaintiff can prove negligence by showing a condition existed for such a length of time that the defendant should have discovered it, but the holding is that the particular circumstantial description of the foreign substance there was insufficient as a matter of law to establish that time element. The case therefore narrows and skeptically treats time‑based inferences from the condition’s appearance, rather than affirmatively supporting that such evidence is enough to show constructive notice in the typical foreign‑substance case like a puddle with tracks through it.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it. … In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence consisting for the most part of a description of the foreign substance.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.raw_text: *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 61 (1983) (duty measured by what a reasonable person would do in the circumstances).
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care required of a business proprietor and constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent focused on proximate causation, not on whether the defendants’ conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care for a business proprietor. While the dissent briefly references the negligence standard and assumes arguendo that certain acts could be negligent, it ultimately argues that negligence was not the legal basis for liability due to lack of causation. It therefore does not serve as affirmative authority that the defendants’ conduct constituted negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969)."

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.raw_text: *Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 320 (2002) (causation requires that negligence be substantial contributing factor).
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s slip and fall and the injuries she sustained.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The proposition is fact-specific, asserting that the defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff’s slip-and-fall injuries. Kent v. Commonwealth does address proximate cause and defines it in terms of foreseeability and superseding causes, but it does not involve a slip-and-fall or hold that negligence was a proximate cause in favor of a plaintiff. Instead, it finds no proximate cause as a matter of law and therefore cannot be cited as authority that a defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause in a slip-and-fall case, though it can be cited for general proximate cause principles.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.raw_text: *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982) (damages include medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering)
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: As a further result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered foreseeable personal injuries and economic damages, consistent with the principles of compensatory damages articulated in, inter alia, *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982) (damages include medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering); see also G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on personal injury damages).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The provided portion of Payton v. Abbott Labs is an extensive discussion of emotional distress, prenatal injury, causation, and identification of manufacturers in DES litigation. It does not discuss or enumerate the categories of compensatory damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, or pain and suffering, nor does it address prejudgment interest. Therefore, this opinion, at least in the cited pages, does not support the specific proposition that damages include medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: The excerpted opinion focuses on whether Massachusetts recognizes certain causes of action for emotional distress without physical harm, wrongful life-type claims, and prenatal injuries, and on market share liability. It does not contain a passage specifying that compensatory damages include medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: As a further result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered foreseeable personal injuries and economic damages, consistent with the principles of compensatory damages articulated in, inter alia, *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540, 549–50 (1982) (damages include medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering); see also G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on personal injury damages).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s own conduct did not cause or contribute to the dangerous condition created and allowed to persist by Defendant. To the extent any comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff denies such allegations and asserts that any such negligence, if found, would be substantially outweighed by Defendant’s negligence and, in any event, would not bar recovery but would only proportionally reduce damages under G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable rules, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
